results.title: In the Wake of the Stars
results.creator_credit: Cinesound, Bede Whiteman and Mark McDonald
results.brief_description: Aviation came quickly in Australia. In the early days reliable DC3’s carried everyone and everything. Then new faster and more comfortable aircraft were sought: the Fokker Friendship from Holland, the super Viscount from France and turbo jets from America. During training flights the attractions of gracious Amsterdam, gay Paris, England’s spring, New York’s people, Rome’s buildings and Australia’s scenic attractions are presented.

results.title: Community College Mt Gambier: growing
results.creator_credit: New Films, South Australian Film Corporation and Justin Milne
results.brief_description: This is the story of the South East Community College Mount Gambier. Features two teachers, Bev Puckridge and Ian Winter, who narrate throughout the film. Shows how students go back to their own communities and set up and teach smaller groups in woodwork, pottery, spinning etc. Emphasis is made that art is a natural part of our world - a natural thing to do. It is not the finished product that really matters, but the thought process used to achieve it.

results.title: Dream
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: A partly animated film based on a series of drypoint prints (‘Movements’ and ‘Combats’) by Australian printmaker Charles Lloyd on the theme of aggression in society. The sound composition by Arthur Cantrill is a mix of percussion and altered piano (plucking and hitting strings and soundboard, played by Arthur Cantrill), sound effects (including breathing), and electronically modified children’s laughter, recorded on a Nagra reel to reel tape recorder and transferred to 16mm magnetic tracks which were laid and mixed in a professional sound studio, where reverberation was added to some sections.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill

results.title: Artists in cyberculture
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Cohen, Frances McGivern and Cracked Metal Productions
results.brief_description: Artists record their work at the Third International Symposium on Electronic Art, Sydney, 1992. Through a series of interviews, performance, electronic theatre, this video looks at ways in which artists challenge the emerging technological realm known as “cyberculture”. It also examines issues such as gender, the body, the homogenisation of culture and the social and environmental implications of new technologies. Three of the artists interviewed are Char Davies, Stelarc and Myron Kreuger.

results.title: You've got to work for it (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A film made by six Diploma of Education students (Bob Sharples, Kamal Monsour, Sally Ford, Derek Burrage, Denis Connolly and Doug Eastman) about the problem migrant adolescents face in Australia. Through group discussions between Italian immigrants, Greek immigrants and first generation immigrant children, a real portrayal of the frustration of immigrant teenagers growing up in Australia is shown. Also gives a brief background history of Greek/Italian migration in the 1960’s and 1970’s from an economical/political point of view. Broadmeadows

results.title: Ten times empty
results.creator_credit: I Wilson, J Tristram and Juniper Films
results.brief_description: A study of life in a Greek village community on the island of Simi, a barren rocky island lying in the Aegean Sea off the coast of Turkey, with particular emphasis on the surrendering of traditional means of livelihood because of changing economic circumstances. Migration is a central theme of the film, with special reference to Australia. Scenes of the island reveal that despite a lack of factories, farming and jobs, close cultural and community ties bind the 3,000 inhabitants together.

results.title: Be smart... don't start
results.brief_description: Especially designed for elementary grades at school, this film looks at cigarette smoking and the hazards of starting the habit. It presents opposing opinions and claims of cigarette manufacturers and medical men in an effort to create a lifetime mental attitude toward smoking at this critical age level.

results.title: Autism: who cares
results.brief_description: Four centres for autistic children in Victoria show how they deal with this problem. Details how they are able to teach the children to eventually integrate into the community. Photographer: Leigh Tilson; Music: Franciscus Henri, Philip Gardner, Audrey Klein.

results.title: The Eye inside
results.brief_description:
“With this work I am interested in questions of personal identity. What is it? Can you capture it in a photograph? What would you need to do in that photograph to be acting as the real you? How can you protect your own sense of identity in the face of external pressure?

Using notorious archival photographs of ‘hysterical’ patients as the starting point, I wanted to re-examine what was actually being revealed in these strange images to us, contemporary viewers. The body language we see was heavily influenced by popular culture of the period, particularly the theatre and religious imagery, and also distorted by the doctors’ trials with hypnotism. But there is clearly a conflict between these female patients’ own sense of identity, emerging as the psychic pain they metaphorically express with their bodies, and that of the male doctors/ photographers’ conception of them.

I was interested in applying a similar pseudo-medical method of observing and photographing to displays of specific contemporary body language: again female, again familiar from popular culture. Would the distinction between personal identity and cultural identity be obvious? How far would these healthy, sane modes of behaviour need exaggeration to be classified as unhealthy or mad? This work is an initial investigation into these themes.”
Cordelia Beresford, 2004.

Duration: 2 x 8 minute video piece, looped as per duration required by ACMI specifications (ie it will play 3 loops continuously if possible- tbc). The second 8 minute piece is a variation
(ie different edit only) of the first. Both are to be played simultaneously on two or more screens.

Shoot Format: 16mm film and 35mm still photographs, both mastered to digital-beta tape. Black & white.

Delivery Format: Digital-Betacam tape, 60 minutes length.

Sound: the work is silent.
